description.p: Storage is an Alpha Anywhere abstraction for dealing with different types of storage using a standard interface. Several types of storage are supported, including Amazon S3, Azure, Wasabi, and Disk storage.

discussion.p: Storage is used for storing files.
To work with Storage you will need a storage connection string to 'connect' to the storage object.
Named connection strings are typically used (in much the same way that named AlphaDAO connection strings are used when you connect to a SQL database).
To create a named storage connection string, select the Tools, Storage Connection strings menu item from the Tools menu when the Web Control Panel has focus.

description.p: This will open a dialog where you can create as many named storage connection strings as you want.
When you create or edit a named storage connection string, the Connection String dialog is shown:
Named storage connection strings are published in the a5_application.a5i file when you publish your application.

section.title: Named Storage Connection String Builder Settings

description.p: The *[ui:Named Storage Connection String Builder]* is used to build a named connection string to a storage container stored in Amazon S3, Azure, or on disk. A description of general settings and settings for each storage type are listed below.

case.title: General Storage Connection Settings
case.description: These are general settings that apply to all storage types.

item.name: Storage Provider
item.description: Where the files are stored. Files can be stored on *[ui:Amazon S3]*, *[ui:Azure]* or on *[ui:Disk]* on the server hosting the Alpha Anywhere Application Server.

item.name: Triple-DES Object Encryption Key (optional)
item.description: If specified, used to encrypt the data in transit and at rest in the data container. Encryption takes place in the Alpha Anywhere Application Server. Click *[ui:Generate a New Key]* to generate a random encryption key.

description.p: If checked, storage connection string will be encrypted using the specified passphrase.
The passphrase used to encrypt the connection string.

item.name: Container Must Exist
item.description: Check if the specified container or bucket must exist.

item.name: Request Timeout (milliseconds)
item.description: The timeout length specified as milliseconds. Used when connecting to or communicating with the storage container. If no response is received after the specified timeout, the operation is cancelled.

important.p: Some Alpha Anywhere features and Xbasic functions do not support encrypted storage connections.

case.title: Amazon S3 Storage Connection Settings
case.description: When configuring a storage connection string for Amazon S3, you will have access to the settings below:

item.name: Region
item.description: The region where the Amazon S3 bucket is located.

item.name: Access Key
item.description: Your Amazon S3 access key.

item.name: Secret Key
item.description: The secret key for your Amazon S3 account.

item.name: Show Secret Key
item.description: If checked, shows the secret key in plaintext.

item.name: Container Name
item.description: The Amazon S3 bucket where files are stored.

case.title: Azure Storage Connection Settings
case.description: These settings are for configuring an Azure storage connection.

item.name: Use Test Storage
item.description: If checked, uses the test storage container for Azure. Test Storage does not require an Account or Access Key.

item.name: Account
item.description: Your Azure account name.

item.name: Access Key
item.description: Your access key for your Azure account.

item.name: Show Access Key
item.description: If checked, shows the access key in plaintext.

item.name: Container Name
item.description: The Azure container where files are stored.

description.p: A "Disk" storage connection can be used to store files outside the webroot on the server running the Alpha Anywhere Application Sever. Using a storage connection is preferred to accessing directories directly using the FILE object in Xbasic, especially if you are using the Application Server for IIS.

item.name: User Name
item.description: The user name for accessing a network share. For deployed web applications, grant the machine and account access to the share instead of putting a user name and password into a connection string. This will simplify management and reduce the chance of someone gaining access to the user name and password.

item.name: Password
item.description: The password for your user name.

item.name: Show Password
item.description: If checked, shows the password in plaintext.

item.name: Parent Path
item.description: The base path on the server to the directory where files are stored.

case.title: Wasabi Storage Connection Settings
case.description: These settings are for configuring a Wasabi storage connection.

item.name: Region
item.description: The region where the Wasabi Storage container is located.

item.name: Access Key
item.description: Your Wasabi Storage access key.

item.name: Secret Key
item.description: The secret key for your Wasabi Storage account.

item.name: Show Secret Key
item.description: If checked, shows the secret key in plaintext.

item.name: Container Name
item.description: The Wasabi Storage bucket where files are stored.

section.title: Xbasic Functions for Working with Storage

description.p: Several Xbasic helper functions make it easy to work with the storage. These helper functions are written on top of the low level storage objects are listed below.

item.name: [a5Storage_saveFile()]
item.description: Saves a file in storage

item.name: [a5Storage_saveData()]
item.description: Saves binary data in storage

item.name: [a5storage_copyFiles()]
item.description: Copies a folder or list of files to storage

item.name: [a5Storage_getItemProperties()]
item.description: Gets information about a file in storage

item.name: [a5Storage_getItem_as_blob()]
item.description: Retrieves an item from storage to a variable

item.name: [a5Storage_getItem_as_file()]
item.description: Retrieves an item from storage and stores it as a local file

item.name: [a5Storage_listItems()]
item.description: Create a CRLF delimited list of items in storage

item.name: [a5Storage_deleteItem()]
item.description: Deletes an item from storage

description.p: Each type of storage has a mechanism for securing the objects stored.
For Disk storage, containers and items are called folders and files. Folders and files are secured using Access Control Lists.
Folders and files can be managed through the Windows user interface.
For Azure storage, containers and items are called containers and blobs. Containers and blobs can have permissions set on them as well.
See [Microsoft Azure Container and Blob Permissions] for more information on security Azure storage.
For Amazon S3 storage, containers and items are called buckets and objects. Buckets and objects can be authorized by user as well as having public permissions set on them.
Below are some examples of permissions you may need to set to manage objects in a bucket:
To verify a storage connection string in the connection string dialog - s3:GetBucketLocation
To list buckets and objects - s3:ListBucket, s3:ListObjects
To read objects - s3:GetObject, and s3:GetObjectVersion
To delete objects - s3:DeleteObject
To store new objects - s3:PutObject and s3:PutObjectAcl
There are many other permissions that you can grant for buckets and objects. See [Amazon S3 Permissions] for more information on security Amazon S3 storage.
